ticket.title: Helpers use safe_concat rather than marking strings as html_safe
ticket.original-body:
The `#concat` and `#cache` helpers in Rails 2.3.6 call `output_buffer#safe_concat` rather than calling `output_buffer#concat` and passing in an `html_safe` string. This is a major compatibility issue for alternate templating engines: Haml, for instance, uses a plain `String` as `output_buffer`, and handles XSS-escaping elsewhere. Rails should never assume that `output_buffer` is a `SafeBuffer`.
This [patch on my Rails fork](http://github.com/nex3/rails/commit/4f16460ded1ec862acd5b2360e4b1e61e72863eb) fixes the issue.
ticket.latest-body:
The `#concat` and `#cache` helpers in Rails 2.3.6 call `output_buffer#safe_concat` rather than calling `output_buffer#concat` and passing in an `html_safe` string. This is a major compatibility issue for alternate templating engines: Haml, for instance, uses a plain `String` as `output_buffer`, and handles XSS-escaping elsewhere. Rails should never assume that `output_buffer` is a `SafeBuffer`.
This [patch on my Rails fork](http://github.com/nex3/rails/commit/4f16460ded1ec862acd5b2360e4b1e61e72863eb) fixes the issue.
ticket.original-body-html:
The #concat and #cache helpers in Rails 2.3.6 call output_buffer#safe_concat rather than calling output_buffer#concat and passing in an html_safe string. This is a major compatibility issue for alternate templating engines: Haml, for instance, uses a plain String as output_buffer, and handles XSS-escaping elsewhere. Rails should never assume that output_buffer is a SafeBuffer.

This patch on my Rails fork fixes the issue.

version.body:
The `#concat` and `#cache` helpers in Rails 2.3.6 call `output_buffer#safe_concat` rather than calling `output_buffer#concat` and passing in an `html_safe` string. This is a major compatibility issue for alternate templating engines: Haml, for instance, uses a plain `String` as `output_buffer`, and handles XSS-escaping elsewhere. Rails should never assume that `output_buffer` is a `SafeBuffer`.
This [patch on my Rails fork](http://github.com/nex3/rails/commit/4f16460ded1ec862acd5b2360e4b1e61e72863eb) fixes the issue.
version.body-html:
The #concat and #cache helpers in Rails 2.3.6 call output_buffer#safe_concat rather than calling output_buffer#concat and passing in an html_safe string. This is a major compatibility issue for alternate templating engines: Haml, for instance, uses a plain String as output_buffer, and handles XSS-escaping elsewhere. Rails should never assume that output_buffer is a SafeBuffer.

This patch on my Rails fork fixes the issue.

version.title: Helpers use safe_concat rather than marking strings as html_safe

version.body: output_buffer is always a SafeBuffer, the rest of the template engines should use this if not this templates aren't safe. I'm opening a new ticket with a fragment_for backport.
version.body-html:
output_buffer is always a SafeBuffer, the rest of the template engines should use this if not this templates aren't safe.
I'm opening a new ticket with a fragment_for backport.
